unnormalised: The office calendar looked like a battlefield. Mrs. Desai, our team lead, was attempting to schedule a critical project review meeting. The initial date proposed was 28/11/2024, but almost immediately, the chaos began. Rakesh from marketing emailed saying he had a client demo prep scheduled for the entire morning. Then Aisha from sales chimed in, mentioning her prior commitment to a training session from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM.
normalised: the office calendar looked like a battlefield. missus Desai, our team lead, was attempting to schedule a critical project review meeting. the initial date proposed was twenty eighth november two thousand and twenty four, but almost immediately, the chaos began. Rakesh from marketing emailed saying he had a client demo prep scheduled for the entire morning. then Aisha from sales chimed in, mentioning her prior commitment to a training session from ten A-M to one P-M.

unnormalised: Next, there was the issue of time zones. Our team in Bangalore needed to be included, and figuring out a time that worked for both them and the Mumbai team was proving difficult. Someone jokingly suggested 11:30 PM IST, which got a few laughs, but Mrs. Desai was not amused. She sighed, “This is like herding cats! Can no one make themselves available even for 2 hrs on a Thursday?”
normalised: next, there was the issue of time zones. our team in Bangalore needed to be included, and figuring out a time that worked for both them and the Mumbai team was proving difficult. someone jokingly suggested eleven thirty P-M I-S-T, which got a few laughs, but missus Desai was not amused. she sighed, “this is like herding cats! can no one make themselves available even for two hours on a thursday?”

unnormalised: The back-and-forth continued. Someone suggested pushing it to 02/12/2024, but then it clashed with the finance team's budget meeting. It seemed every proposed time slot had some sort of conflict. Even a brief 30-minute catch-up call was turning into a logistical nightmare. I checked my own calendar; a small window had opened up on 29/11/2024 from 2 PM to 4 PM. I cautiously suggested it.
normalised: the back-and-forth continued. someone suggested pushing it to second december two thousand and twenty four, but then it clashed with the finance team's budget meeting. it seemed every proposed time slot had some sort of conflict. even a brief thirty minute catch-up call was turning into a logistical nightmare. I checked my own calendar; a small window had opened up on twenty ninth november two thousand and twenty four from two P-M to four P-M. I cautiously suggested it.

unnormalised: To everyone's surprise, it worked! Only Rahul from HR had a minor conflict, but he preponed his interview by an hr and agreed to join. Mrs. Desai sent out a final confirmation email with the subject: "Project Review Meeting – FINALLY Confirmed! 29/11/2024, 2:00 PM – 4:00 PM."
normalised: to everyone's surprise, it worked! only Rahul from H-R had a minor conflict, but he preponed his interview by an hour and agreed to join. missus Desai sent out a final confirmation email with the subject: "Project Review Meeting – FINALLY Confirmed! twenty ninth november two thousand and twenty four, two P-M – four P-M."

unnormalised: A collective sigh of relief echoed throughout the office. We all knew that scheduling a meeting, especially one involving multiple departments across different cities, was an art form in itself. And sometimes, a little bit of luck, combined with a lot of coordination, was all it took to find that perfect 2-hr slot amidst the chaos.
normalised: a collective sigh of relief echoed throughout the office. we all knew that scheduling a meeting, especially one involving multiple departments across different cities, was an art form in itself. and sometimes, a little bit of luck, combined with a lot of coordination, was all it took to find that perfect two hour slot amidst the chaos.
